description.text:
Brackets for mounting a 2.5" drive in a 3.5" bay. Made to fit the twist lock system in my NZXT Tempest case. Included Inventor part file if you need to change the spacing or hole tolerance. Plastic-saving design with a small footprint that reduces the chance of warping. Symmetrical design for easy install. You may need to rotate it so the flat side is down.
EDIT: Added the Slim variant that removes one of the cross beams. It offers a slight increase in print speed, decrease in material consumption, a tiny tolerance adjustment for the overall width, and reduced chance of lifting.
EDIT: Added double slim variant for mounting two drives in a single slot.
Gravy

title: E Z Open Door Lever Adaptor

description.text:
Make opening doors real easy with this lever style adaptor.  It installs in minutes and is designed to work with a common Qwikset 1.875" (47.6mm) diameter round door knob.
To open door simply apply a downward force with one or two fingers and pull door forward.  A knurled area provides a non slip grip.
A single #6 x 1/2 inch long sheet metal screw clamps the adaptor tightly to the door knob, it can be mounted for left or right hand operation.
Available in two sizes, small lever (-s) or large lever (-l), Solidworks files attached so you can modify it to fit any door knob.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.20mm to .25mm

Infill:

25%

Notes: The print time is approximately 45 minutes for the small lever (-s) and 70 minutes for the large lever (-l)

STEP 1: Remove supports along bottom and in screw hole with small knife or flat screwdriver
STEP 2: Push the #6 x 1/2 inch long screw into the bored hole
STEP 3: Push lever adaptor over door knob and adjust position
STEP 4: Tighten screw until lever adaptor is firm and snug Optional:
To prevent any slipping, wrap 1/2 inch wide masking tape over center of knob before attaching lever adaptor

title: LG G Watch Charging Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I recently purchased this Black Stainless Steel Watch Band for my LG G Watch. It looks great, but makes it impossible to use the charging cradle flat as it was designed, as the watch band doesn't open completely. Instead you have to put the cradle inside the band to charge the watch. This isn't terrible, but it's not great either. Plus, charging the watch flat on a table has no added utility. I set out to design a stand that holds the charging cradle so the watch could be placed on it from one side. If the cradle was tilted at enough of an angle it would also allow you to use your watch as a clock. The G Watch is perfect for this as the screen is always on. So there I was, naively thinking I was the first person to have this idea. Turns out I wasn't, but that's okay. This is probably a common occurrence for people when they first get into 3D printing. I soldiered on and created something that meets my needs perfectly. Now it sits on my nightstand. It's very stable and it's working great as a clock. The stand is set up for use with the original USB cable. It would likely need to be modified if using a different cable. A friction fit cable management channel has curved corners to avoid bending the cable too sharply. I then went a little nuts and chamfered all the edges in the model, but I think it looks pretty nice when printed. There were a few flaws in my print, but I blame those on improper printer calibration rather than my modeling.

comments.text:
Great creation..! Thanks for making it available. Two thing I would suggest.
1.Use support so the cable slot, charger bay, and USB slot come out nice and straight.
2.Drill a hole on the back, as seen on photo, in case the fit is too tight and you need to remove the charging dock to refit. Otherwise you either scratch the dock or crack the edges of the cradle.

description.text:
UPDATE:
I've uploaded "Box Short.stl" and "Lid Short.stl" which are 62.5% of the original height of the box for those not requiring the size of the original box.  These components also include a minor improvement in the design of the hidden corners for assisting in holding the box closed.  I test printed both components and they printed fine.
END OF UPDATE.
I've seen many of these over the years, the latest I found a few years ago made of wood.  This 3D printed version is a very simple, yet pretty effective "secret" box.
Even with pretty close examination, it appears as if there is no way to open the box.  Only by gripping the correct opposite corners on the correct end and pulling, will the box open.
Designed using Sketchup Make 2015, and printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42 "Standard" Settings (.2mm layer height, 2 shells, 10% infill).

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

10%

Print "Box.stl" and "Lid.stl".  I highly suggest the build plate be precisely trammeled before printing, and not too "tight" (e.g. print head not too close to the build plate).
Test fit and trim, file, sand, etc. both parts as necessary for smooth insertion and removal of "Lid.stl" into "Box.stl". Depending on the colors you chose and your printer settings, more or less trimming, filing and/or sanding will be required.  
Assemble as shown in "Assembly.skp" or "Assembly.stl".
Feel free to comment if you have questions.
Hope you like it!

comments.text: I printed the short version for my grandson, who is coming to visit for the first time since I got my printer.  I'll put some folding money in it to increase the interest in cracking it.  I scaled it to 0.6 and it printed well at 0.3 LH with a .4 mm nozzle.  Slic3r dropped the connecting thread on the corner locks on the lid, but the small piece was attached by virtue of lack of resolution.  The lock fits well, but the top rocks on the locking axis when it is pushed.  I may weld a stop in the corners to make it more difficult to crack the puzzle.  I printed the box w/o infill and the top without and again with infill.  Slic3r seems to drop a top layer when there is no real top, so the two shells aren't joined on the edges that fit inside the box, but otherwise it is fine.  I wasn't sure how it would handle printing the two bands on the box without infill, so I printed the internal perimeters first, and it came out well.  Thanks so much, I enjoy your stuff!

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:529563 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=529563

Using the following options: thickness = 1
type = AAAA
custom_diameter = 14
custom_length = 50
batteries = 3

This model is base on the Allison 1000 automatic transmission. Is not an exact replica but the basic design and functionality are the same. The most significant difference from the real transmission is the C1 and C2 clutches that I design to work with 3D printed parts and solenoids. Assembly video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vvhICaIRjOY Gear ratios:
1st: 3.20
2nd: 1.86
3rd: 1.43
4th: 1
5th: 0.70
6th: 0.60
R: 4.41 I made the lower part of the case quite big so there's room to put solenoids to engage all the clutches and even a parking pawl to control them with switches or even change gears automatically with something like Arduino. The selector 3D model is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1214373 For more information about how to make the electrical part to control the solenoids, go to my project page where I show the circuit diagram and arduino sketches: https://sites.google.com/site/interlinkknight/allison1000 Here's the Arduino sketch and circuit for controlling the solenoids: https://123d.circuits.io/circuits/1579637. This sketch uses a potentiometer as the selector, and a switch for manual mode. In Drive mode will change between all gears sequentially after a period of time. There's a second sketch for realistic operation where changes gears automatically considering speed and how much the pedal is depress (require a speed sensor on the output and a potentiometer for the pedal). Also has manual mode, manual override, delay engaging clutches, display, etc. If you want this sketch, go to the project page. There is also an adapter to fit this transmission to the Toyota 4 Cylinder 22RE Engine made by ericthepoolboy. This is the adapter: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1120974 I don't have a 3D printer so I would appreciate any feedback from people that printed one to improve the model. Still, I check all parts on Cura to make sure all is ready to print, except the orientation. You will have to rotate some parts to print it in the optimum way to have the least overhanging and warp. A special thanks to the user RobinSwa for helping me improve the model by testing it and giving me useful feedback.

You need:
  • 1mm rod
  • 3mm rod
  • 21 self threading screws to fit on a 1mm diameter holes
  • 2 self threading screws to fit on a 2mm diameter hole.
  • Several washers/spacers for the 1mm and 3mm rod.
  • 1 snap ring or E-clip for the 3mm rod.
  • 2 ball bearings 608ZZ - 8x22x7mm (inside diameter x outside diameter x width)
  • 6 push/pull solenoids with a body size of 30x15x15x30mm (LxWxT). I recommend this one: DC 12V 1A 10mm Stroke Push Pull Type Open Frame Solenoid Electromagnet
    http://www.amazon.com/10mm-Stroke-Frame-Solenoid-Electromagnet/dp/B00HR8H38A
    • The file names are self-explanatory. Print the number of times mention on the file name and assemble like shown on the video. Use the 3mm rod for the center of the transmission and for the clutch forks. The 1mm rod is to hold the planet gears to the carrier. I recommend putting washers in all planet gears and each side of the 3mm center rod. All the rods have parts where it should be fixed to a part very tight by pressure and another part where it should be lose so it can turn in that axis. For example on the planet gears the 1mm rods should be fixed to the carrier and the planet gear holes should be drilled so is big enough to turn easily. As I show on the video, you need to put a snap ring or E-clip after the C2 clutch to hold all the planetary gear sets together. To do this you need to create a notch on the rod. I recommend begin the assemble from output to input, like on the video. P1, P2 and P3 are the names of the planetary gear set, numbered from input to output. If you don't know the name of the parts of a planetary gear set, here it is:
  • Sun gear: the gear in the middle
  • Ring gear: the big gear that covers all the gears
  • Planet gears: the gears that go between the sun gear and the ring gear
  • Carrier: the part that holds the planet gears

description.header: Video of my engine that will go with this transmission
description.text: <iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/B2LqtCjqjEU" ></iframe>

06/05/2016
  • I make a hole on the internal part of the case to put the speed sensor near the parking gear. The parking gear is suppose to interrupt the IR light in the other side, in an angle.
    • 05/28/2016
  • I divided each fork into 2 pieces to make possible the assembly. The previous forks had an included extension on the bottom to reach the solenoids, but that would prevent the forks getting in to the case in the way is suppose to (from the front). Now the extensions can be added later using a screw with nut. Thanks for the user Hank190 for pointing out this mistake.
    • 04/30/2016
  • Reduce the angle of all helical gears in all planetary gear sets, so I re-upload all those parts. The reason I change this is because I want to use this transmission with a load and having a high angle on the gears (like before) it creates too much longitudinal force.
  • Remove the basic/simpler version that uses buttons to apply the clutches, so now there's only the solenoid version. This is because is harder to keep updating 2 versions of the same transmission, and the solenoid version is after all the way I planned to use this transmission.
    • 03/23/2016
  • Increase the diameter of the input and output shafts from 8mm to 8.1mm because the inside diameter of the bearing is 8.1mm.
    • 03/16/2016
  • Put a hole for a nut on each side of the C1 Clutch so there's no need for the screw to cut through the plastic (that was not very strong). I put 1 on each side so is balance. Also I add an included spacer so there's no need to use that many washers between the clutch and the input.
  • Now the 2 sliders use the intermediate shaft as axis for more stability. Also the contact part to the forks was moved.
  • Remade the two forks because they not longer need to support the sliders, so they now have a smaller contact surface with the sliders, and also fit with the new sliders position.
  • C2 Clutch is a bit longer to fit better.
  • Input and output now have dipper holes for the intermediate shaft, so the shaft can work to stabilize the input and output (avoid side play).
  • I made the shaft for the P2 Carrier - P3 Ring a bit longer.
  • Before, the P2 Sun - P3 Sun had 1 hole for a screw. Now there is one on each side so is balance. There is no space for nuts, but a good option could be glue this part to the intermediate shaft, using this 2 holes so the glue has something to hold on to.
  • A bit bigger support for the fork rods in the Solenoid Case. Also those supports were moved a bit forward to avoid touching the spring of C3 clutch that is near by.
    • 03/13/2016
  • A little better hook for the spring on C3 clutch.
  • Add a dipstick. Is optional, but I think is a nice touch.
    • 03/12/2016
  • Both cases were improve with more cosmetic details and there's a hole to make space for the bearing on the output side so the bearing don't touch the wall. Also, now there is a place for 2 magnets to hold the top cover, and put tops/limits so the cover stays better in place.
  • Add the 2 holes for the magnets on the top cover.
  • Fix a minor aesthetic detail on the oil pan.
    • 03/09/2016
  • Add some included spacer on the bottom of the P2 Sun - P3 Sun to fill the space to the output.
  • Now all the 3 planet carriers have the holes for the planets going all the way through so is easier to remove the 1mm rods.
  • Now all the ring gears have an included spacer so they now all touch each other in the outside part. Before, I tried to make the contact part on the inside to reduce friction, but I realize that is better to have stability, and friction don't seem so bad because those parts print much smoother than the inside.
    • 02/17/2016
  • New hook for spring on C3 clutch, fixing a mistake of the direction of the spring.
    • 02/16/2016
  • Add C-Clip that goes on the C2 clutch.
    • 02/15/2016
  • Increase the internal hole in C2 clutch so is easier to fit in the tube.
  • Edit the front cover so it has a space for the inside part of the bearing to prevent it from touching the wall. I will later do the same for the output part.
  • The input and output has a included spacer so the outside of the bearing don't get in contact to the input and output.
  • Fix the P1 Carrier - P2 Ring so it has thicker walls in the carrier part, so the small rods of the planet gears have better support.
  • Small fix to P2 Carrier - P3 Ring, but mostly irrelevant.
  • All planet gears were reduce in size to 98% so everything turns smoother.
    • 12/06/2015
  • Convert all the parts to have only one shell. Before, I made the mistake of making each part with multiple polygons join together, but later when someone tried to print them it broke off where each polygon touch to each-other. Now is fixed.
    • 11/12/2015
  • Change the place for the screws on the oil pan, so I had to update both cases and the oil pan.
  • I remove the extra support of the rods on the front cover to give more space to the clutches.
  • I had to increase the internal hole of "P2 carrier - P3 ring" to be able to insert the sun gear.
  • Add C1 and C2 clutch forks for the solenoid version.
  • Improved C3, C4 and C5 clutches for the solenoid version.
  • Further improve the parking pawl to engage better with a solenoid, calculating using a solenoid model with the correct measurements.
    • 11/11/2015
  • I change all the ring gears exterior so the end of the notches where the clutch engage is vertical to avoid the solenoids clutches from disengaging if the force is stronger of what the solenoids can give. This don't affect the default version since it uses buttons.
  • Redesign C3, C4 and C5 solenoid clutches to a lower position and the edges now are vertical.
  • For the solenoid case I lower the holes for C3, C4 and C5 clutches.
  • I improve a little the parking pawl so is easier to engage by a solenoid.
    • 11/09/2015
  • Add 2 realistic cases: one for using with buttons to engage C3, C4 and C5, and another case for using with solenoids.
  • Add buttons to engage C3, C4 and C5.
  • Add clutches for C3, C4 and C5 to engage with solenoids.
  • Better clutch fork with more support.
  • Longer shaft for the input.
  • Longer shaft for the output.
  • Add parking pawl for the solenoid version.
    • 11/06/2015
  • Improved C2 Clutch to prevent the P1 Sun Gear from moving forward.

comments.text: Hi mate, I was just checking this for a while, and as you made this I would like to ask you something. I'm about to start a project of a realistic FPV RC car with a gas engine, and the idea is to put a two speed manual transmission + reverse. I had been checking around for a while already and I cannot find something like that already made so I will get into building or modifying something. Do you think it is a good idea to use this concept to build a manual transmission (With the same functionality shown in the video but speeds manually activated with some solenoid/servo). The thing is that using a real manual transmission will require a clutch, and for RC cars I found nothing, all transmissions I saw for RC cars are automatic and based on centrifugal clutches, and building a clutch (correct me if I'm wrong) could be much harder that building just the gear box, not because of the technology, but because of materials used. I would really appreciate your feedback.
comments.author: OPSO

comments.text: Hi, OPSO. If you want to use my transmission, or any other transmission, to use with high speeds and load, you do need a clutch. You could try changing gears at high speed and load without clutch but that could damage the transmission very quickly.

comments.text: I thought about it and I think the best option is to split each fork in 2 pieces. The problem appear when I put some extensions on each fork so it could reach the solenoids, and that lower part is what prevent it from getting into the case. So I think the best would be make the extension as a separate part that screws into the fork. The screw would be on the front of each fork so you could remove it without needing to remove the solenoids. As is right now, I don't think you could remove all the main parts of the transmission without needing to remove the C2 solenoid. So my plan of splitting each fork in 2 pieces would not only make possible to assemble the forks, but also would allow to remove all the main parts of the transmission (gears, sliders, forks, input, output, etc) without needing to remove any solenoid on the lower part.

title: Glue, Accelerator and Light Machine Oil Caddy

description.text:
No springs, no motors, no gears; just a compartmentalized box. 
I designed this compartmentalized box to securely hold the glues, accelerators and light machine oils I use while assembling machined and/or 3D printing projects.  Protecting the glues, accelerators and light machine oils from being bowled down by my errant desktop tested designs (e.g. "Windup Helicopter") and spilling across the desk, this caddy keeps them securely in place in the "highly likely" event of a collision, especially the glues (minimizes trips to the acetone tank).
Trammel the build plate before printing.  I've added hold down disks to the corners to assist in avoiding warping.
Designed using Sketchup Make 2015, and printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42 "Standard" Settings (.2mm layer height, 2 shells, 10% infill).

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

10%

Notes: Trammel the build plate before printing. Takes a long time to print.
I added hold down disks to the corners to assist in avoiding warping.  After printing, carefully remove them with a modeling knife.

description.text:
This is an early draft of my submission for the noisemaker challenge. The idea is easy customization and the ability to "compose" tunes. While the musical character may be limited I can imagine this appealing to children as a way for them to build/customize a music box. The system works like a typical music box, the cylinder would contain ridges which lift the arms. These arms then hit back, creating sound. What differentiates this from other designs is the ability to re-arrange these ridges. The system holds 32 rings on a splined shaft that has been optimized for 3D printing. There are 16 "flaps"-each with different characteristics (8 lengths+2 thicknesses) that can be actuated by these rings. This will inspire experimentation since we all know that kids love to make noise.
If anyone has any questions, comments, or critiques please let me know.

description.text: This is a tile-based system for building a micromouse maze. Print the posts and the walls in white and the floor in black. The black tiles should interlock to allow you to make any size maze. WARNING: 13-Nov-2015: I am still developing this. Just created a new floor model and increased the size of the peg on the post.
I designed this in OpenSCAD based on the Micromouse Rules found here, http://micromouse.fatoni44.com/design_report/2007MicromouseRules.pdf

comments.text: @helicron I am going to make the peg thicker. I have a wood and metal maze that has a metal peg for the post and it works fine. I'll experiment with the printed post. Also, I plan on changing the floor tile design to make it easier to print.

comments.text: Interesting idea. You may want to make the peg that holds the post in a lot more substantial. Crashes are common and likely to break a thin support peg like that. Japanese and Taiwanese contest mazes use at least 9mm diameter pegs.

description.text:
This is the shell of EFSmartCarV14. To assemble the car, put the shell on the Ultrasonic of the EFSmartCarV14.
The EFSmartCar series is created by ELECFREAKS. It is a multi-function car. We create 7 lessons to make users study easily. It can help us to improve our thoughts to develop multi-function car if we've grasped how to use the sensors. For example, Infrared and Ultrasonic help us understand how to avoid obstruction and check distance. IRremote can help us understand how to control the car. FindLineModule can help us understand how to use sensors and set up the truck of car. And also the buzzer which is in on the car can play songs if we write programs for it. At last, there is a switch on the car can be used to check collision.
For more details please check out this page: http://www.elecfreaks.com/wiki/index.php?title=Arduino_Advanced_Kit_-_EN

Needed to collect small 3D printed bits and put in little bags or compartments of a sorting tray.    
UPDATE of 28/10/2015
There are now a couple of variants to the original design.  The first variant is dimensionally the same as the original but can be printed in two pieces.  This allows the scraper end to be printed at 0.06mm layer height and still have three layers at the tip of the scraper which, obviously, is pretty thin!  The second part can be printed faster and then the two super glued together (or acetoned for ABS).
The other variant has raised walls for helping to scoop up meds.

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

100 microns

Infill:

25%

Notes: Printed in ABS as I think it makes for a smoother surface but PLA would likely be just fine!

I made these simplified DNA model chips for students who learn about DNA and RNA.
These chips can be joined, stacked and twisted using fine wire to present the basic structure of DNA and RNA. Students learn very quickly if they have something to play with in their hands. I recommend you to print each chips (A,T,G,C,U) in different colour, to see the difference between each nucric acid entities.
Please note, this model has been radically simplified, so tell students about this is not really showing the every detail. I printed and used these models for explaining the process of reproduction and transfer of information in genes. If you want worksheet and teaching plans, please email me. Hope you find some use of this!

3x 10mm Self Adhesive Felt Pads One thing I missed in the video is right at the beginning on the M6 bolt used to tighten the extending portion of the tripod. Cut one of the 10mm felt pads to fit the size of the end and attach. This will prevent the bolt from eating into the aluminium tube when tightened.

description.text:
Impact absorbing legs for a T copter. Parts List:
4x M6 Coach Bolt and Nut (65mm length)
4x C-612 Compression Spring
4x Printed Parts Assembly is pretty straight forward.
Thread bolt through the landing bud. Place the compression spring onto the bolt, past the thread. Insert nut into the slot in the leg. Thread bolt into nut until the end. Repeat x4. Attach to copter.

Designed in Onshape Took Brendan22's original file, converted and imported it into Onshape. Used only the clip and cable tie portion and removed the rest. Modelled the rest with an M6 Coach Bolt in mind. The file is public if you wish to have a look or edit.
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/37a1410632a24af79e020ba1/w/92a96dc250264b898ef436f6/e/04c5d648cd8146549f8a8481

author: Enrico57

title: RigidBot rod holder excenter to adjust non paralell Y rods.

description.text:
My rods where originally bent ( up to 0.2mm) This is how I maid them straight.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=alWesY-0t1E
( i used the 2 X rods as rulers intsead of tha glasplates = testing the 2 Y rods)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mRtIxG2co5w My frame is not 100% squere. The Y rods are 0.1 mm not parallell. The effect is that 3 corners is possible to get at the same level. The forth corner is "the non paralell amount" off. Adjusting this corner moves the problem to the crossside corner.
I had to do one offset mount tho get the Y axis parallell.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:952107
This is just the concept. You must make your own with the offset needed.
(This process takes hours.. And I am now totaly baldheaded) Look at the X gantry. Are the Z bearings att the same height? If not the X gantry bars holding the bearings are not parallell. This adjustment do not make much effect. The non paralell Y axis makes a big improvement.﻿ My first adjustable rodholder has a hole as a mark used as indicator for where the offset is. I turn the rodholder to try to fine tune the offset. Then I created a new fixed rodholder with the tested offset.

comments.text:
To be honest I do not think that this mod does wonders for the printing quality, but IMO it aids as it relieves the load of the left Z axis construction. Like the dual z ax rod constructions. As any irregularity in the z rod will move the entire z carriage if there is play in the right side.
I designed it because I noticed that my z axis was not running smoothly, and noticed skipping issues with my z axis stepper. I found that this mod made it all run smoother. And together with another mod which eases the pressure on the left rods, I was able to solve and improve my issues. BTW I will post the left bearing alignment mod later on this week.
Z wise I am happy with the results of my printer now, but have to fix some x y weight related issues.

description.text: Feel free to print and sell prints / props / casts molds whatever. Your time, your plastic - go for it.. It's a fan based model so bare in mind that means I don't  hold the rights to it, so that responsibility falls back to the maker if you are selling props.

I have made a small modification to parts 3 and 4 - if you printed them already I am sorry, but don't worry, it was an addition not a fix! :) I put the small details that go on the sides of the helmet (the little round bits) I also have uploaded the full helmet in one massive STL, if you have a printer big enough to print it in one go, then I envy you! As promised to many people, here is the Episode VII wearable helmet. This is considerably different to the other smaller Ep7 helmets as it now follows the contour more of what we have seen in the trailers. I have based the size of this off my previous Stormtrooper helmet (which was 33cm wide) this new one is 30cm wide as it doesn't have a rebreather on both sides on the new version. All pieces have been plated ready to print, checked for errors and all parts triple checked they are the right number etc. The youtube video explains the parts and where they go, which can be found below or in the thumbnails above. I have not had a chance to print this yet, and I probably won't until after the movie so in the spirit of good will and fellow Star Wars fans, here are the parts. If there are any issues at all please let me know and I'll correct them ASAP but I've been pretty thorough on this one so I'm hoping it should be smooth sailing. I was going to add the extra's, but someone uploaded one that works pretty well, just heat up and shape to your helmet. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1342259 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6sy6WCLoxH0

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3 is Ok as its going to be sanded

Infill:

Very low, if not none. Use 2-3 walls/shells.

Notes: All Parts were designed to be printed on a Makerbot Replicator / Flashforge size machine, ie 22cmx14x15, if you need something cut into smaller pieces, please message me.

This set was originally going to be a remix of the very cool spiral set by BigBadBison. I couldn't get them to print neatly on my printer at the scale i wanted and my intent was simply to beef up the spirals. I kept making other small changes to my liking and it dawned on me that i could just make my own set, so i started from scratch. All pieces where built from the ground up in Sketchup (the only 3D modeling program i know how to use) except for the knight, i borrowed the beautiful horse from TimEdwards openscad chess.
Some slicers have problems with my stl files. Ive fixed them all and run them through netfabb, they should work with all slicers now.
May 16 -  Uploaded a new king. Made a few changes to the original.
July 2, 2017 - Uploaded a zip file with the original Skecthup files for anyone who may want the originals. The models have holes in them which would have been time consuming to fix so i let netfabb repair the exported STLs.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20

Notes: Printed with Matterhackers PLA at 200°
The kings cross prints out separately and fits into the recess in the crown. Depending on your printer tolerances, this may be a nice tight friction fit or it may be loose and need to be glued in.
Sketchup

Wheelchair Storage (or For Whatever You Want)
When you think of wheelchairs, more often than not, you probably think about people who have an aid who walks around with them. What about the other type, the type of people who push themselves around in wheelchairs? They don’t have aids who could carry their things around for them. The areas on their wheelchairs have limited space for storage, so what if they could have a holder to attach to their wheelchair and help them carry their belongings? It would change the way they do things. It would be a very useful idea.
Not only is it good for holding your belongings in pouches, but it also has a holder for a water bottle. It even has a drawer that slides into the slot on the front to hold anything you want it to.
To put it on your wheelchair, it has areas for straps to slide through and keep it on your wheelchair securely. This is a great addition to the original design of my holder, because now, it won't fall off if you hit a bump.

Holder It is designed to fit onto or strap onto a wheelchair. It is a very beneficial item. Changes I had to make a second strap area on the top of the holder so that it would actually strap on. It was an easy change, but I still had to do it. Water Bottle Holder Who wants to carry their water bottle on their lap all day? Anyone? No. Of course not! Why would you hold it all day long when you could put it in the Holder and finally have your hands free for something fun. You could be reading, texting, or even writing poetry. No matter what you want to do, it sure is helpful not to hold that water bottle! Drawer Have you ever had to carry around tiny objects, like business cards, or I guess even marbles? Well now you can carry those things around so much easier in a drawer. It's like having your desk with you at all times. Don't lose your marbles, just get a holder!

This bowl is made by using a laser cutting machine at f.Labo in Japan.
The material is MDF 2.5mm.
You can bend it to your favorite shape.

1.Cut
2.Wet with tepid water.
3.MDF is softened.
4.Bend to your favorite shape.
5.Fix it with a bent state.
6.Dry it. You can make your original one using this cutting patterns.

For more details, please visit us at www.ascentaerosystems.com, and get the instructions to assemble this model at http://www.ascentaerosystems.com/model.

author: mirjampartou

description.text:
Here is a modified version of Zach's Plastruder design.  These layers replace the ones inside the MK4 plastruder to help guide the Idler Wheel.  This keeps it straight and on target.  I have managed to crush filament without so much as a crack on the acrylic idler wheel.
I still wouldnt recommend crushing filament just because you can...but this will atleast keep you from replacing an idler wheel every so often.
NOTE*  The rendering engine on Thingiverse makes the files appear wobbly, but when loaded into the proper software they should show perfectly round.
Laser cut and replace each layer.

comments.text: I'm  glad to see that the thingiverse has reached the point where large upgrades and replacements of entire subsystems for a machine that can make more things.

description.text:
This is a flywheel cage for use in Nerf blasters, intended as an afterburner cage. Sourcing wheels has been difficult, but the cage design is here, open-source. The newer design has a bit of extra cage diameter capacity for 2-3/8" wheels. Posting this for my Nerfer friends. Wheels and hubs can be bought from BaneBots: Wheel, 2-3/8" diameter, 50A durometer rubber tread
http://www.banebots.com/product/T40P-245BA-HS4.html Hub for T40 wheels, 2mm shaft attachment:
http://www.banebots.com/product/T40H-SM21.html Note: The hubs have been discontinued and are on closeout, and an additional nylon press-fit bushing is needed, 1mm ID, 2mm OD. Shouldn't be too difficult at all. Update: The new design is made to not require rafting. And who in their right mind tries to put press-fit mounts on a 3D printed piece? Me apparently. Fixed that too.

comments.text: Which blaster(s) is this intended to fit in? Thanks!
comments.author: JHROX

comments.text: homemades and externally as an afterburner. it doesn't fit inside the blaster. It's massive.

comments.text: Well, getting those hubs balanced is a huge pain. The housing printed very nicely, and the motor mounts are gloriously clean. It's made to have a brass sleeve inside as a dart guide, which takes some dremel work, or file work if you're diligent. The BaneBots wheels are surprisingly balanced, but it's still difficult to do right.

title: Four sided 70-80° overhang test with 30mm bridging.

description.text: I made this test to map the cooling performance of my Cobra cooler ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1090433 ). It tests the ability to cool overhangs from four sides. It also has a sensible 30 mm square bridging test, which corresponds to the kind of bridging you might encounter on real prints. Optimizing your printer for 100+ mm bridging is silly in my opinion because it compromises performance in real life scenarios.

No

Notes: I print my tests at 50 mm/s with 50% outline speed and three perimeters and top/bottom layers.

This prosthesis has been designed to help those people with missing fingers. It has been modelled keeping in mind the following principles:
-Keep the number of printed parts as low as possible
-Keep the assembly process as simple as possible
-Use the least possible amount of non-printable parts. The bolts and nuts in the joints have been replaced by bits of 1.75mm filament.
-Leave openings in the model to allow the hand to transpire
-Allow a higher degree of freedom in the wrist The fingers flex when they are pulled by strings, such as fishing line, and extend automatically with the help of elastic cord. A fabric strap with velcro is needed to secure the prosthesis to the arm. The model is open-source, and thus can be studied and modified to improve its performance.
https://youtu.be/0TF3ih02L9A Author: http://www.soniaverdu.es/

english : it's comming soon francais :
Voici la première trompette, designé pour être facilement imprimable en 3D!
il rete encore un peut de travail sur les ressorts mais c'est bientot fini ^^ Elle est composé à 100% de pièces en plastique et n'en nécessite pas d'autres.
Elle est constituée de 4 parties principales:
-le corps, composé de la chambre, le couvercle, 3 ressorts, 3 pistons, le bouchon de la voie d'eau et les fixations. C'est la partie centrale de la trompette.
-le tuyau d'accord de la trompette sur le côté pour pouvoir ajuster le ton de la trompette
-les 3 tuyaux pour les 3 tons classiques (1/2 ton, 1 ton et 1.5 tons qui restent encore à tester)
-le pavillon j'ai construit cette trompette en laissant une grande marge à de possible évolutions, surtout basées sur les parties tubes, ils ont tous le même embout d'accroche. Vous pouvez jouer sur la longueur du tuyau d'accord et changer le ton de votre trompette d'un ton, un demi-ton, un ton et demi etc. Coupler cela avec les 3 autres tuyaux et vous a des possibilités presque infinie !
Une fois la limite de taille dépassée, le pavillon à aussi une grande possibilité d'amélioration. Astuce : pour un meilleur jeu, Il faudra prévoir une peu d'huile ou de vaseline sur les pistons

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Yes

0.1mm

20%

Francais : Contruite pour etre fonctionnelle et simple, La pt'ite trompette est faite de facon solide et economique en plastique, une fois la partie chambre, pistons, ressort, etc... imprimé, les autres parties sont modifiable selon vos desirs.(vu que je travaille encore dessu, je vous le conseille fortement ;) )
Elle est adapté a tout les nozle inferieur a 0.5 mm et elle est imprimable sur une surface de 10x10x12.5 cm (les critéres d'une très grande majoritée des imprimantes du marché :D )

comments.text:
bonjour a toi ! oui je préfère parler français (en fait j'ai eu la flemme de traduire la présentation en anglais et je ne suis pas assez bon pour faire un si long discourt :S)
Alors en réalité pour cette trompette, je n'arrive a avoir qu'un son relativement ... moche (c'est dus au imperfections de mon imprimante)
J'ai fait les pistons un poil trop gros, du coup il faudra les poncer un petit peut.
Vus que j’étais partit sur le principe de garder tout imprimable, les ressorts en plastique fonctionnent plutôt bien mais ils ont tendance perdre en force assez rapidement et les pistons de remontent plus totalement, idéalement tu devrais prendre des ressorts avec une longueur d'environ 20 mm et 10 mm au maximum pour le diamètre
il faudra surement faire un petit support pour les tenir en place (je peut te les faire si tu veut ;) )
Dans l’ensemble sache que c'est la première trompette que j'ai modélisé, je l'ai faite en copiant au mieux les distance mais vu que je n'ai pas réussi à en jouer il faudra surement faire encore quelques petites modifications sur les différents tube (meme si c'est un peut le principe de base)
pour le lissage, je n'ai pas de bon conseils j'ai fait une sorte de lissage/bricolage avec une mélange d'acétone et d'eau qui m'a foiré la chambre pour les pistons du coup je doit me la réimprimer et j'ai un peut laissé trainé depuis le temps :s
tu pourrait tenter avec du sable fin et secouer la trompette.

author: CallJoe

description.text:
In front of our house, we have a nice letterbox. Unfortunately, one day, I accidentaly broke the key inside the lock (fortunately in the open position). So now, very often, we find the door open ... And, if it rained just after the postman delivered some letters, we also find some water inside! This is not good for the letters. I tried to remove the lock but, for some reason, I can't. And anyway, when I went to the seller of this letterbox or to a DIY shop, they didn't have this type of lock (note a probably similar one can be ordered - with no guarantee it would be fitting - but it costs more than 3D printing it ...). So that's why I decided to start this project. It is fairly simple: why not wrap around the right side of the door an object that could:
  • act as a handle to open/close the door (now that we can't insert any key - that was another function of the key - and probably the reason it broke) ;
  • somehow keep the door in a closed position (thanks to a part of the object between the door and the letterbox).
    • Note that I don't need the door to be closed with the key. We are living in a safe neighborhood and it's not in the habit of people to have a peak at others' mail (well, you never know ... maybe for a second project?).
Letterbox handle in 123D Design

Yet another flashlight bike mount? Jup! Why?
  • Customizable
  • Easy to print
  • Uses very little plastic
  • Requires no screws or bolts
  • Has strap holes as well as a snap-fit design for the flashlight
  • Adjustable angle (sideways)
    • Update: fixed internal spacing.

• Customize for your bike, flashlight and straps.
  • Print.
  • Attach to handlebars.
  • Snap in your flashlight and strap it down.
  • Go for a ride! :-)
    • Tip: make the flashlight mount as tight as possible. I set the diameter to 1mm less than the actual diameter of the flashlight. Double-sided velcro is ideal as a strap for the flashlight, but inner tubing, rope, or whatever else you have lying around will work as well. For attaching it to your handlebars, ty-rips work best. A small piece of inner tubing also works well for added grip between the mount and the handlebars. For added visibility, don't forget to print a diffuser for your flashlight! (Like this one, or a short version of my flashlight cone, as seen in this thing's pictures.)

description.text: This water rocket kit is part of the Learning in a Makerspace chapter of my new book "The Makerspace Workbench" from Maker Media! Simply 3D print the nozzle and cut out a set of fins to convert a soda bottle into a high-flying rocket. Use 100% infill and keep the pressure low to prevent unintended explosion. For best results when launching, create a simple launcher that holds the NPT quick-release in place out of a piece of 3" PVC and an end cap. I would not recommend launching this with your hands. Be safe!

To launch, secure the fins onto the bottle and add a small ball of modeling clay to the top of the rocket. This will help stabilize as it flies. Fill the bottle with a small amount of water and screw on the nozzle. Insert the tapered end of the nozzle into a standard NPT quick-release air fitting, pump up to about 40PSI, release the fitting and watch it fly!

comments.text: You can use it with or without water. I just did a contest for a 7th grade class.  It goes much higher with water, but it will work without.   Anyone know what size o-ring??

title: Scouts Woggle for JOTA - amateur radio annual event

description.text: This is a JOTA woggle as you might find around the neck of a cub or scout, and even some beavers or girl guides. This was a simple design made by me ( Denis - M0USV ) for the GB2COS Cestrian Scouts event in Cheshire UK. See http://www.gb2cos.org.uk JOTA stands for Jamboree On The Air and is an annual event where scouts all over the world are encourages to operate communication stations including amateur / ham radio stations to work towards their communications badges and widen their skills. Inclusion of new technologies like 3D printing makes for a excellent demonstration while producing something that they can find useful for their scouting activities. With some care you can paint in the letters with a sharpened matchstick and some nail varnish. I would recommend leaving the inner as rough as possible to provide a little friction and grip on the handkerchief.

title: 1.5 Inch Feet for 0.25 Inch Round Bolt Heads
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/26HHatk3rZl These are 1.5" feet designed to receive a 1/4" 20 turn round head bold to act as leveling feet for any type of project where needed. In short you can use an epoxy (like this one http://amzn.to/1POKNxh) to secure the bolt "firmly" in the printed foot and two 1/4" nuts (top and bottom) to level the device. Or you could also use inserts (i.e. http://amzn.to/1LVfDhK or http://amzn.to/1POKUc8) as the top of the foot also has a round head which can be adjusted too. Note: the second file (prefixed with print) is the file you want to "print" as the other one just shows them assembled with simulated bolts. For more information on projects such as these can be found at http://www.DIY3DTech.com

author: jacopolupi

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/5MKlcsYP29d

title: Camera Mount for Remote Print Monitoring

description.text:
This design is intended to facilitate mounting a small USB camera (specifically a ELP-usb500w02m-l21) on a vertical surface, with a good degree of flexibility in orientation. I've specifically used this to mount one of these cameras (the 170 degree field of view version) inside my R2X. Once I had the orientation that I wanted, I fixed the ball-and-socket in place with glue. In the position shown in the photo, I get an excellent view of the nozzle as it extrudes, a nearly complete view of the build plate as it drops, and the carriage will not hit the camera/hood. The "hood" piece is optional and can be used to shield the lens from a light source. In my case I wanted to prevent the bright LEDs in the front of my R2X from impacting image quality. I've built a small raft into the hood piece to provide a starting point for supports; it is easily snapped off after printing. 12mm M2 screws can be used to attach the camera to the mount by simply screwing into the plastic (no need for nuts on the back). The bracket can be attached to the vertical surface using #10-32 machine screws or similar. A 3/16 inch drill bit can be used to
ensure the holes in the mounting bracket are sized for the #10 screws. The camera output is processed using an ODROID camera and VLC. This allows the video stream to be viewed from another machine with VLC or similar over HTTP. A sample VLC command line that works for me is:

/usr/bin/cvlc -I dummy --no-interact \
v4l2:///dev/video0 :v4l2-standard= :live-caching=60 \
:sout="#transcode{vcodec=h264,vb=512,scale=1,fps=5,acodec=none} \
:http{mux=ts,dst=:8080/cam}" > /dev/null &
 I'll be honest that working with VLC can be maddening for me, so please do not ask me to help debug :). Good luck!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes
